metadata.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Extension Officers

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 2524 of 1967 filed by 12 Extension Officers in the Department of Industries, Government of Andhra Pradesh.
Extension Officers appointed as such in May 1961, underwent training, posted in various districts.

Strength of cadre of Extension Officers reduced, leading to retrenchment of some personnel including petitioners, who were absorbed in another cadre viz. Senior Inspectors, resulting in diminution in scale of pay.
Persons appointed later and juniors to petitioners retained as Extension Officers, whereas petitioners retrenched by order dated September 28, 1967.

Juniors retained instead of following last come first go rule by reason of residence in Telangana area; preferential treatment on basis of residential qualification discriminatory and violative of Art. 16.

Admitted in counter affidavit of Government that except Telangana employees posted only in Telangana region (to which Andhra personnel cannot be posted), no juniors of petitioners allowed to continue in preference to petitioners.

Mulki Rules formed part of Hyderabad Civil Service Regulations promulgated in obedience to Nizam's Firman dated 25th Ramzan 1337H; State of Hyderabad native Indian State not acceded to Dominion of India post 1947.
Chapter III Article 39: No person appointed in superior or inferior service without sanction if not Mulki per Appendix N; cancellation of domicile leads to dismissal.
Appendix N Rule 1: Person Mulki if (a) by birth subject of Hyderabad, (b) by residence entitled, (c) father completed 15 years service at birth, (d) wife of Mulki.
Rule for permanent residence 15 years, abandoned idea of return, affidavit.
Rule 7: Contents of application for Mulki certificate including prior residence, birth, abandonment of native land.
Rule 9: Govt may cancel Mulki certificate if incorrect entries, false, or disloyalty.
Historical conditions in Hyderabad: Isolated, inadequate education, Urdu official language, locals unable to compete without residence protection.
Constitution Article 35(b) for continuance of such laws.

States Reorganisation Commission recommended separate Telangana; agreement by leaders of Andhra and Telangana for 5 years unit for recruitment to subordinate services using Hyderabad domicile rules; Regional Standing Committee.
Agreement clause B: Temporary 5 years, Telangana unit for recruitment, posts reserved for domicile per Hyderabad Rules.
Constitution Seventh Amendment Act 1956 substituted Art 371 for regional committees etc.
State of AP reconstituted on November 3, 1956.
Appendix N amended post 1950 with explanation referring to circulars; circular June 14, 1950: Mulki Rules saved by Art 35(b) except inconsistency, put out birth/descent requirements.
Circular Sept 18, 1951: 15 years residence continuous except education/medical breaks.

High Court proceedings: Order July 9, 1969 in WP 2524/67; Writ Appeal 633/70; reference to Full Bench of 5 judges Dec 9, 1970; Full Bench majority held Mulki Rules not valid post AP formation, not revived per Narasimha Rao case; overruled Lakshmana Rao case.
Division Bench allowed Writ Appeal with costs per Full Bench opinion.
Public Employment (Requirement as to Residence) Act 1957 commenced Dec 7, 1957? Wait, text says December 7, 1957 but later March 21, 1959.
Act came into force March 21, 1959; rules same date.

legal_issues.text: Were r. 1(b) read with r. 3 of the Mulki Rules (impugned Mulki Rules) and Art. 39 laws in force immediately before commencement of Constitution in territory of India?
Were they continued in force by Art. 35(b) of the Constitution?
Did they continue in force after constitution of State of Andhra Pradesh under Re-organisation of States Act, 1956?
Did they stand repealed by s.2 of Public Employment (Requirement as to Residence) Act, 1957 (Act 44 of 1957) notwithstanding s.3 declared void insofar as Telangana?

petitioner_arguments.text: Impugned Mulki Rules valid and operative; continued under Art 35(b); not affected by States Reorganisation; s.2 of 1957 Act not applicable to Telangana as s.3 void.

respondent_arguments.text: Mulki Rules discriminatory, unjust; not valid post AP formation.

court_reasoning.text: Impugned Mulki Rules were laws in force before Constitution; territory of Hyderabad included in India.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agreed by all judges; Art. 35(b) and 372 cover Indian States.

court_reasoning.text: Continued by Art. 35(b) as laws re matter in Art. 16(3) i.e. residence requirement for employment; not invalidated by being part of larger scheme.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art. 16(3) empowers Parliament on residence within whole State.

court_reasoning.text: Continued post 1956 Reorganisation; Art. 35(b) ignores reorganisation unless Parliament amends/repeals; purpose of reorg not to take away fundamental rights.
S.2 of 1957 Act repealed existing laws but s.2 and s.3 inseparable scheme; s.3 void for Telangana hence s.2 also void for Telangana; Parliament intended substitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Severability principles apply; history, preamble, Art. 371 support.

holdings.text: Impugned Mulki Rules were laws in force before Constitution.
Continued after Reorganisation of States Act 1956.
Not repealed by s.2 of 1957 Act for Telangana as s.2 void insofar as Telangana.

precedents_cited.case_name: P. L. Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench decision cited but matter referred further.

precedents_cited.case_name: V. S. Narasimha Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Held s.3 of 1957 Act and r.3 of rules ultra vires for Telangana.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lakshmana Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench overruled by AP High Court Full Bench.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. D. Chamarbaugwala v. Union of India

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Saved Mulki Rules under 35(b); residence under 16(3); regional provisions.

statutes_cited.name: States Reorganisation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Constituted State of AP; did not repeal Mulki Rules.

statutes_cited.name: Public Employment (Requirement as to Residence) Act, 1957 (Act 44 of 1957)
statutes_cited.relevance: S.2 and s.3 void for Telangana; repeal not effective.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgments of Full Bench and Division Bench of AP High Court set aside; Writ Petition No. 2524 of 1967 dismissed. Mulki Rules held valid and operative in Telangana.
outcome.relief_granted: None to writ petitioners (respondents); status quo on retrenchment upheld.

key_quotes.text: "The impugned rules continued in force even after the constitution of the State of Andhra Pradesh under the Re-organisation of States Act, 1956."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We hold that s. 2 is also bad insofar as it dealt with Telengana area."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason s.2 of 1957 Act ineffective for Telangana.

key_quotes.text: "This is a matter for Parliament and not for us."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court defers policy on Mulki Rules fairness to legislature.
